channel.title: Flappy Fowl - my fangame/remake of Flappy Bird
channel.description:
Hey Moparscapers,
I made a clone of the Flappy Bird game since the [B]original got removed[/B] by its owner and cannot be downloaded anymore. I aimed to make Flappy Fowl [B]as similar to the original as possible[/B].
If any1 has an Android device, you can download it here:
[url=https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.thingymagic.FlappyFowl&hl=en]https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.thingymagic.FlappyFowl&hl=en[/url]
[IMG]http://i.imgur.com/PSsJIOa.png?1[/img]
Please post your opinions of the game and any suggestions here into this thread and [B]I'll reply to every suggestion[/B]. Or if you think it's good enough already, you can rate it on the Android market.
Also feel free to share it with your friends - this is hot topic currently and I'd greatly appreciate any publicity you could give me.
Thanks. :)

item.title: Flappy Fowl - my fangame/remake of Flappy Bird
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

[quote=“Vain_, post:26, topic:539944”][quote author=xx matty xx link=topic=658794.msg4407618#msg4407618 date=1392501594]
Well surely the entire point of app signing is to stop people doing just that? I’ve never actually tried so I’m not sure, but I’d expect non-jailbroken devices to verify the certificate of an app before running it.

Obviously if something’s on the app store and someone uploads it, then yeah you can transfer that to your device and it’ll work fine because the certs are valid.
[/quote]the code is signed with the developer’s certificate.
if the certificate expires, whether the app is still in the store or not, the app will still be able to be ran/installed

as long as the app does not try to pull files from a non local database (such as pulling updates from a website/etc - mostly used in games) the app will be able to be installed at any time, on any device, as long as the codebase is up to par with the current OS

if you have the ipa for an app, you can install it any number of times to any device as long as it’s compatible with the iOS at hand.[/quote]

Google Play requires applications to be signed until 2033 (possibly 2034 now).

Read full topic
item.source: Flappy Fowl - my fangame/remake of Flappy Bird

item.title: Flappy Fowl - my fangame/remake of Flappy Bird
item.dc:creator: @botdoge botdoge
item.description:
@botdoge wrote:

He used a bot for the reviews and 5 star ratings which has been proven because 6 months after the game was released on the app store one day it just blew up and 90% of the reviews are repeatedly negative but still have 5 star ratings. He still makes 50k a day. This guy is a genius.

Read full topic

item.title: Flappy Fowl - my fangame/remake of Flappy Bird
item.dc:creator: @Vain1 Vain_
item.description:
@Vain1 wrote:

[quote=“xx matty xx, post:25, topic:539944”]Well surely the entire point of app signing is to stop people doing just that? I’ve never actually tried so I’m not sure, but I’d expect non-jailbroken devices to verify the certificate of an app before running it.

Obviously if something’s on the app store and someone uploads it, then yeah you can transfer that to your device and it’ll work fine because the certs are valid.[/quote]the code is signed with the developer’s certificate.
if the certificate expires, whether the app is still in the store or not, the app will still be able to be ran/installed

as long as the app does not try to pull files from a non local database (such as pulling updates from a website/etc - mostly used in games) the app will be able to be installed at any time, on any device, as long as the codebase is up to par with the current OS

if you have the ipa for an app, you can install it any number of times to any device as long as it’s compatible with the iOS at hand.

Read full topic

item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

Well surely the entire point of app signing is to stop people doing just that? I’ve never actually tried so I’m not sure, but I’d expect non-jailbroken devices to verify the certificate of an app before running it.

Obviously if something’s on the app store and someone uploads it, then yeah you can transfer that to your device and it’ll work fine because the certs are valid.

Read full topic

item.title: Flappy Fowl - my fangame/remake of Flappy Bird
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“xx matty xx, post:23, topic:539944”][quote author=Vain_ link=topic=658794.msg4406511#msg4406511 date=1392153862]

[quote author=ixia link=topic=658794.msg4406506#msg4406506 date=1392153445]
Selling my iPhone for $50000, it has flappy bird installed! lol
I’m serious on eBay search ‘iphone flappy bird’.

You can still install flappy bird on android if you can get the apk or if your iphone is jail broken.
[/quote]you don’t need to have it jailbroken. you can down the ipa online and move it to your phone via iTunes
[/quote]That wont work forever, I’m pretty sure the certificates n shit will expire and you can’t get fresh ones without re-publishing the app to Apple.[/quote]
Can’t programs like iFunBox install apps to the iOS? I don’t know if it requires the jailbreak, but it’s what I use to extract/replace files on my iDevice that’s jailbroken.

Read full topic

item.title: Flappy Fowl - my fangame/remake of Flappy Bird
item.dc:creator: @Revamp_dis_Shit Revamp dis Shit
item.description:
@Revamp_dis_Shit wrote:

[quote=“ixia, post:20, topic:539944”][quote author=Revamp dis Shit link=topic=658794.msg4406769#msg4406769 date=1392231573]

The developer stopped Flappy Bird because it had highly addictive qualities…so he wanted to put an end to it.

He got death threats etc.

No…
http://bgr.com/2014/02/11/why-flappy-bird-was-removed/
http://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/gaming/2014/02/11/flappy-bird-creator/5388515/
[/quote]
Would you remove your game if people where addicted to it? Especially when there was already a lot of remakes of the game.[/quote]
Read the damn internet then… and yes I would if I was in the right state of mind… And remakes? The game just came out and JUST starting getting popular… any remakes were made immediately after it was closed down…
But, then again, if you don’t believe me… then I don’t give a fvck lol… I told you the answer so live with it and move on.

Read full topic

there may be more to the story, but this is what i would assume as i’ve seen all the aforementioned.[/quote]

item.title: Flappy Fowl - my fangame/remake of Flappy Bird
item.dc:creator: @HoMM HoMM
item.description:
@HoMM wrote:

Yeah, but removing the game from the marketplace doesn’t remove it from the peoples phones who already have installed it.

And the people who still have it installed will probably keep playing it. (obviously not as much once the hype slows down, but he will be still making plenty off of the ads)

Read full topic
item.source: Flappy Fowl - my fangame/remake of Flappy Bird

item.title: Flappy Fowl - my fangame/remake of Flappy Bird
item.dc:creator: @noobs_are_ftw noobs are ftw
item.description:
@noobs_are_ftw wrote:

[quote=“HoMM, post:7, topic:539944”]But the thing is - he is still making that exact same money.

Everyone that downloaded the game still has it. And it actually might have a benefit for him in the long run - now that the game is officially discontinued, people are even less likely to uninstall the game. And if people don’t uninstall, he keeps making the same kind of ad revenue.

It’s pretty interesting to think about it.[/quote]

well i dont think so because you have to actually play to game to generate the ad revenue

Read full topic
item.source: Flappy Fowl - my fangame/remake of Flappy Bird
